title: How do I get my wage garnishment lowered?
question: I owe on medical bills and the collection agency's attorney filled to have my wages detached. They are currently taking 25% of my income. I am a single mother of two and cannot afford to support my family on my income now. I have already filed for and exemption but it was disallowed pursuant to CCP 706.051(c)(1). I have tried to work with the collection agency and there attorney but neither is willing to help. I tried to get a second job but it will only cover the cost of daycare while I am working it and that is just point less. Please help!
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Debt,Wage garnishment,Bankruptcy and debt,State, local, and municipal law
answers: In response to your follow-up question posted in the additional information field, a civil money judgment ordinarily would be dischargeable in bankruptcy.

California law permits 25% of your income to be levied by wage garnishment. A claim of exemption allows the judgment debtor to reduce the percentage where leving the full amount creates undue hardship. But, a claim of exemption will be denied where the underlying debt was incurred for the common necessaries of life such as medical care, under Code of Civil Procedure section 706.051, subdivision (c)(1).

The denial of your claim of exemption does not mean the judgment creditor cannot agree to take less than 25% of your income. The Financial Statement (Wage Garnishment -- Enforcement of Judgment) form you filed with the claim of exemption may have justifed a reduction in the amount levied had the debt not been incurred for the common necessaries of life. In these circumstances, a creditor may agree to voluntarily reduce the amount levied. A rational creditor realizes that, if it wants to continue collecting money, it is in its interest not to make the wage garnishment so difficult the debtor quits her job or files bankruptcy to stop the garnishment.

Based on the information provided in your question, you have already tried to negotiate with the collection agency and its attorney to reduce the amount of the levy without success. You may now wish to contact the health care provider directly to see if the it may be willing to foregive the debt due to financial hardship. If those efforts fail, you should consult with a bankruptcy attorney to discuss your situation and for specific legal advice about your options.
25% of your income seems like an unreasonably high number. Make sure your state law allows such a high percentage.
